timeline.bodyText: The logic in the lines above (setting root instance id and removal time) is only necessary when the authorization is created, not when it is updated. I think it would be good to only perform it in the creation case to avoid unnecessary queries for the root process instance.
timeline.author: ThorbenLindhauer

replies.bodyText:
When we only do it on creation, we miss the following case:

A user creates a historic task authorization manually
The user (1) realizes later that there is a typo in the task id or (2) wants to change the authorization from ANY to a concrete task id
No root process instance id is assigned

This is counter-intuitive for the user.
replies.author: tasso94

replies.bodyText: Isn't that case covered by the changes you made in SaveAuthorizationCmd via CAM-11617? When the user fixes the authorization, then it automatically receives the root instance id.
replies.author: ThorbenLindhauer

replies.bodyText: Sorry, I did not pay enough attention to the exact code and mixed both places up. I think you are right.
replies.author: tasso94

timeline.bodyText:
In case of standalone tasks (root instance id == null), we don't have to go looking for the root instance.
Which removal time should a standalone task permissions receive?
timeline.author: ThorbenLindhauer
ThorbenLindhauer

replies.bodyText:
An already assigned task cannot be claimed. Consider these changes [1]
The purpose of the test is covering the identity link behavior in general; It does not really matter which API method is called to create the identity link
My proposal would be to rename the test method

replies.author: ThorbenLindhauer

timeline.bodyText: Nitpicking: The //then part of the test begins here. For me, the most important aspect of the given-when-then structure is that I can quickly understand which functionality is tested, so the when part should contain only the statements that trigger the code under test.
timeline.author: ThorbenLindhauer

replies.bodyText:
My understanding is the following:

when refers to the next line of code
then refers to the assertions
code lines between when+ 1 and then retrieve data in preparation of the assertions
replies.author: tasso94

replies.bodyText: Okay, I see the role of then differently. It should include the code that fetches the data. I can already find assertions easily by looking for assert* lines. Maybe we can discuss this in the next team meeting and clarify our testing best practice. I don't mind if we merge this PR in one way or the other.
replies.author: ThorbenLindhauer
